commentBody: I refuse to refer to it as anything other than the Tappan Zee Bridge. Fun to see clues about salt in both the Mini and Full
Pardon me, But most people refer to the Big 10 school in Happy Valley as Penn, not PSU. Otherwise fun puzzle
Finished the puzzle and then spent the next 5 mins figuring out where my spelling mistakes were. Oh well, fun Tuesday puzzle.

Personally I found this way too hard for a Tuesday. I was *this* close to turning on auto check, and only some guesses and a lookup or two helped me avoid that.

I found the SW quadrant incredibly tricky and full of unknowns. KINESTHESIA, CRONUT (???), KHAN (this I remembered from some past puzzle in the end), TROTH (???), the strangely clued SENT all being intertwined almost ended up being my undoing. I'd expect such an accumulation of unusual words and proper nouns on Friday or Saturday maybe, not Tuesday!

What is TROTH?

How does "thrilled" solve to SENT? I seem to remember something from a previous puzzle or comments to one. Song lyrics? Baby you send me? What weird usage this seems to me...

There were unknowns for me elsewhere, too. TOLLHOUSE COOKIE I only got from crosses, and not knowing the product I had no idea how it had anything to do with chips. I needed the column to grasp how this was a themed entry. Chocolate chip... Ok.

BTW: in my many years online I was surprised to learn many Americans love chocolate chip cookies but frown upon raisin ones. Apparently discovering what one thought were chocolate chips are in fact raisins is a major first world problem in the US. Raisins are very popular in Poland, and I don't know a single person who doesn't like them. I always have a bag of raisins on hand, and they are one of my favorite snacks. My wife adds them to cakes, too.

This was not a bad puzzle, but damn was it hard for the day the editor ran it on!
Just came to say it's the Tappan Zee

Who had "some" at first for [more than a few]? Or have I had a few too many?

A timely reminder in a cheery puzzle, undoubtedly composed in better days. 

What are they chipping away?
What will we have to chip in?
Why did he call the CHIPS act "horrible"?

Loved having both Erika Sanchez and Sonya Sotomayor ... and when you cross them you get Sonia Sanchez, another great voice.  And also the theme and Ms. Sanchez bring to mind Erik Estrada, star of "Chips." They make a welcome Latin vibe to the puzzle, or perhaps Tex-Mex (if you count Oilman Pickens), with taco salad & chalupa heading the menu, washed down with one (solo) cup of an ice cold cerveza. Mmm. 

And a goodly amount of (uh...) schwa sounds? Dahlia, aruba, opera, chalupa, eras, kinesthesia, mania, sonia, erika ... pretty schwatastic...

Yep. We will all have to chip in,

This one had several plurals and past tense words I ended up having to go back through and recheck. KNEel instead of KNELT, POSts/POSEs instead of POSED. And I definitely had POKERfAcE instead of POKERGAME. I need to read more carefully! This was a good Tuesday for me though, didn‚Äôt have to look anything up ‚ò∫Ô∏è

Non NYer here having to look up Tappan Zee and delighted to find a lovely painting, a Washington Irving story, and who the Tappan people were, as well as explaining why it‚Äôs spelled Zee instead of Sea. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tappan_Zee

This was fun‚ÄîI kept slopping in typos and wrong answers (for instance POWER for POKER and trying to figure out how wINE was going to work with the down clue when I got there), hitting the down direction key when I meant to go across, and generally making a mess of things, but miraculously, it all came out just fine and I had a good time.  

Thank you, Barbara.  Cute Tuesday.
Might just be me but I think ‚Äúmean, median or mode‚Äù is disappointing clueing for STAT. Nothing to indicate it‚Äôs an abbreviation

Since Sam Cooke has appeared tonight, check out this ridiculously talented fellow doing A Change is Gonna Come: https://www.classicfm.com/discover-music/instruments/violin/sam-cooke-change-gonna-come-vocal-duet/ It will send you!

Ok.  

When I was in college, I was at a seminar on X-ray Crystallography.  I was very excited about it, and then the speaker said "of course you need a computer to analyze the data".

I was still using a slide rule.  I figured I'd never be within ten miles of a computer.

Fast forward....

One of the answers in the puzzle is DESKTOPCOMPUTER, and I'm thinking, jeez, that's really kind of a relic of the past, isn't it?
It‚Äôll always be the Tappan Zee to me.

I was very confused by all comments about the Tappan Zee Bridge, which I must have breezed right past because I didn‚Äôt see it in the puzzle anywhere, until I realized‚Ä¶ oh. It‚Äôs the Mario Cuomo now. 

Not a very popular name change, I‚Äôm guessing?

I breezed through this puzzle thinking it was really easy and then, like others, had to go back and figure out all the places I went wrong: POwERGAME instead of POKERGAME RuCKus instead of RACKET KINESTHESIs instead of KINESTHESIA By the way, here's an article about the difference between KINESTHESIA and proprioception, which is what I first thought of when I read the clue, but it wouldn't fit, even though I tried to cram it in like one of Cinderella's evil stepsisters trying on the glass slipper. https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/neuroscience/proprioception-and-kinesthesia

"What do you think of my tortilla chips?"
"Nacho best work."

(My humor's pretty cheesy.)
The Divine MISS M (Looks funny in the grid); TOLL HOUSE COOKIES; and DAHLIA, there's a lot for me to like in this somewhat Toughened Up Tuesday from Ms. Lin. Enjoyed it.
EENSY? Another one to add to my mental list of tiny words‚Ä¶
ITL that I misspelled AXLE.  Too much figure skating on my mind!  Kudos to our U.S. contingent at the World Championships.   Here‚Äôs to  hoping Lutz will some day be clued instead of Axel.

I did not love the "Erika" -- "Miss M" cross, since one is obscure and the other susceptible to crosswordese renderings. E.g. "Mrs. Em."  It took at least this solver some annoyed staring, knowing one answer and completely without clue as to the other, after everything else had yielded easily.

It's possibly just a function of being someone who has had some sort of personal DESKTOP COMPUTER for a longtime (a programmer), but I absolutely consider 'error' a verb: if you do this, and then that, then the bit of code over there will error.
Nice crossword. I should have got VERBS more quickly than I did. When I was in New York we always had rye bread with caraway seeds - delicious.
Not a piece of cake.
I done did this puzz

Tough Tuesday for me. Had to look up a couple of things early on, but then it was just a lot pondering and working the crosses. And... I really wasn't getting how the theme worked until I stopped and reviewed and pondered after I was done. Just made for a great 'aha' moment. 

Two thumbs up for this one. 

Quite unusual puzzle find today. I'll put that in a reply. 

...
Devine!

A chippy chiparoo of a puzzle!

And now it‚Äôs 6:40am and
I want a taco salad and warm cookies.üç™ 

Why not? 
I‚Äôm doing it!

Adulting is lame.
Except for the part that you get to
have tacos for breakfast.

That‚Äôs the best part.
A fun theme and today I had a lucky break of adding Nestle chocolate chips to my granola before starting to solve this one.

A fun one this morning.  Guess I'm not all that "chipper" because it tugged in a few places.  Well done. 

A TIL on the Tappan Zee.

Harder for me than a typical Wednesday by 36%.  An enjoyable workout.

Barbara, you can‚Äôt leave us hanging. What was the name of the chip?
There are eight Ks in this grid.
I think ‚Äúdoissant‚Äùwould sound better than CRONUT.

They just need to figure out how to safely squeeze a few chips into my aging brain, and I will be glad to have internal access to that cool kinaesthesia app: ‚ÄúFind My Left Foot‚Äù. For going down stairs in the dark, among other things.

Not sure if the puzzle suggests a Lin‚Äôs Law, of doubling the complexity of each chip-themed clue as you go down the puzzle? Fun, in any case.
A clever and fun theme, but glad that I wasn‚Äôt the only one who didn‚Äôt think this was a Tuesday puzzle.  I wonder what tomorrow will bring.

Got stuck in the left center and had to resort to a puzzle check. No gold star for me today. I never reveal. Only check. 
I couldn‚Äôt easily come up with kinesthesia as I‚Äôm more familiar with the word proprioception. A quick google search reveals they are largely interchangeable in most cases, just not in a crossword puzzle! üòú
Didn‚Äôt realize it was Wednesday!
Surprised to see that this was a faster than usual Tuesday for me - So I guess I ‚Äúgot‚Äù it more than I realized while solving - Enjoyed it!

If I just had a nickel for every TOLLHOUSE COOKIE I baked in the course of my 77+ years....  or even for every little taste of the COOKIE dough (after I put the CHIPS IN)...I wouldn't be fretting about the meltdown at the NYSE.  (Actually, I'm not fretting; when you are absolutely powerless, turn your attention elsewhere.)

24D was a gimme.  _Sensory Perception and the Child_ (author J. Ayres) was part of my "extended educational experience," (otherwise known as parenthood.)  Our son was found to need occupational therapy for "Dyspraxia."  (Because he was "achieving above grade level" he did not qualify for this help through the school system, so guess who won the apprenticeship?)  Learned a lot, but the best solution was hiis outgrowing the need to "cut and color" and my teaching him typing/ keyboard skills long before there were little computer programs to do that.  He (and I) remain "gravitationally-insecure."  (Heights are a problem.)  

Oh, yes--great puzzle with fun clues in a variety of subjects.  I seem to recall previous encounters with Barbara Lin.  Brava!!

Gad. The only thing I fear more than a grid rich in American sports references is one, like today, with American food references, particularly if they're referred to as "treats", which pretty much guarantees I won't have a clue.
I should by now recall the name of ELIE Wiesel and the KHAN Academy, but of course I don't. Had RuCKus for RACKET, and POKERfAcE for POKERGAME (while thinking grumpily that a face isn't an activity).
So that was an epic slog for me.

Not a big fan of EST for a guess, unless it's short for something other than "estimate", or I'm missing some subtle wordplay. An estimate as anything but guesswork.  [But spare me the dictionary link, thanks. I'm aware that people use it that way, just as they use "theory" to mean "stuff I just made up" and "research" to mean "reading my social media".]

This is not a complaint.
This was a perfectly pleasant Tuesday puzzle, neither too easy nor too hard.

But,...
In my not-too-limited experience,
TACO SALADs don't have CHIPS IN them, rather they are served in one large, fried tortilla.
One might say that the edible bowl was an enormous CHIP, but even then the SALAD's IN the CHIP, not the other way around.
I suppose there must be places in world where TACO SALADs just have CHIPS sprinkled IN them.
To people who regularly each such things all I can say is, "You're missing out on the real enchilada."

Mmmm, TACO SALAD.  Such a nice choice at a Tex-Mex restaurant when I want to eat "healthy".

Nouns have a way of becoming verbs so I can imagine "error" being used as a verb one of these days.  I was going to use "task" as an example ("I'm going to task you with leading this project") but according to google task was used as a verb over 500 years ago. It did give me a list of nouns that became verbs: mail, stop, sleep, drink, cup, dress, fool, among others.

When the chips are down you can count on a fun puzzle from Barbara.

Hey, there‚Äôs an idea for a vertical theme.

What a fun puzzle. The theme was clever -- dare I say, chipper?

This Canajian fills in the known words, and waits for the Tex-Mex foods to reveal themselves. After thinking I would have to look up the name of a palace,  I got a real kick out of 63A (doh). In the end, I filled it all in with no lookups. Lots of tricky, fun clues.

More from Barbara Lin, please!

P.S.: Chips... chocolate... mmm... must have some.
To me, it always was and always will be the Tappan Zee. You just cannot make up a cooler name than that.
I'm not sure if these puzzles are getting harder or I'm getting dumber... Or both!
Fun puzzle. Finished in one second over average
Solved this one over a glass of tea on my sofa. Relatively quick! Perhaps you could call me a couch potato chip. :)

I thought the rule was that if the answer is an abbreviation, there needs to be an abbreviation in the clue as well?
So I got a bit delayed thinking that REORGS and STATS couldn‚Äôt be correct.
It‚Äôs a tiny (eeny?) point, but a DORMER is the structure that holds the window. It‚Äôs the roof, of whatever shape, and the ‚Äòcheek‚Äô walls, not the window itself.
What you gonna do when the chips are down? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MUQSEXyQsw4
CHALUPA crossing TACO SALAD? Sounds like our constructor made a run for the border. Happy Taco Tuesday, everybody!

Another puzzle full of food! I was actually eating a TOLLHOUSECOOKIE when I sat down to work on it. Serendipitous! 
I, too had "ruckus" before RACKET, but ELIE Wiesel to the rescue! 
Just right for a Tuesday morning.

I did really badly on this one. Totally ruined my Tues average. The NW nearly killed me. I kept wanting ‚ÄúBluffer‚Äôs activity‚Äù to be something related to raising or all in. For some reason I had The Divine MUSES. Having cash to spend was HOLDING. Thrilled was AWED. I‚Äôm going to go POUT now.

Again with the abbreviation answer (5d) that's not indicated in the clue. 
Even looked it up on Merriam Webster's website to be sure, and yep, the only entry there is "abbreviation for Reorganization"

Fun puzzle, aside from that one picked nit

With the many posts about the Tappan Zee Bridge, I thought I'd add one about the Tappan Zee. Borrowed from Wikipedia:

The Tappan Zee (also Tappan Sea or Tappaan Zee) is a natural widening of the Hudson River, about 3 miles (4.8 km) across at its widest, in southeastern New York. It stretches about 10 miles (16 km) ... Its name is from the Tappan people of the Lenape, and the Dutch word zee, meaning a sea.

So although the new bridge is in a slightly different location than the original, it certainly still spans the Tappan Zee. Hope the old name is soon restored.
Does anyone actually refer to Penn State as PSU?  Asking for a friend.

Like many, several initial entries were wrong which made this hard, in a good way. It forces me to be flexible.

Being a neurologist has been helpful in the past, but not today. I wanted proprioception or a variant to work so badly. While KINESTHESIA is technically wrong (it‚Äôs awareness of joint *movement). I think the clue is appropriate enough for a lay audience. Great puzzle!

Somehow came it at 7 minutes under my average today! Got theme clue pretty quickly, although I first thought each related answer would have an omitted "chip" in there. Overall, a great puzzle!

A few bits that were a little crunchy for me:
ASAP not having reference to it being an abbreviation
Thrilled = SENT? never heard this definition
EENSY (need I say more?)
and TROTH, which I've also never heard but assume it is short for betrothed?

This puzzle was so much fun! My last spot to fill was the Big Ten school in Happy Valley. Thanks for the smiles, Barbara Lin. Seemed like a perfect Tuesday level to me. Nice to have something to smile about. üòä
And I always enjoy your comments too, Sam. üòä

My usual late puzzle find. This one was all in the clues, but thought it was quite clever. A Sunday from January 21, 2001 by Con Pederson with the title "Small-town headlines." Some theme clues and answers: "STATE DESTROYED BY MOUNTAIN LIONS" CATSKILLNEWYORK "STATE TOURISM INCREASES AMONG ORDINARY FOLK" "PLAINVIEWNEBRASKA" "PARISIAN TEAM HANDILY DEFEATS ALL-STATE SQUAD" FRENCHLICKINDIANA "CITY AGENCY DECEIVES STATE LEGISLATURE" COUNCILBLUFFSIOWA And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/21/2001&g=108&d=A ...
Finished but didn‚Äôt finish so spent a few minutes to discover I had typed RUBGY instead of RUGBY. Ha!
Took me a long time to realize scratch (out) was eKe, not eXe.

You know that I rarely nit any picks but KHAN is spelled wrong. It's KHAAAN. Three As! This is an indisputable truth. üòâ https://www.youtube.com/shorts/TA0ykZJCOKg Anyhow, really nice puzzle and a fun theme! I had a CHALUPA just yesterday, which is not a frequent thing at all, so fun to see it in here crossing TACOSALAD. Lots of good food references and one of my two favorite flowers (DAHLIA) to boot! I'd have gotten EMMYS on the crosses anyhow, but because of a recent puzzle that I think asked for what she's holding, it was a nice gimme.

Fun! Took a bit longer than most Tuesdays (a) while I tried to figure out to rebus in CHOCOLATECHIPCOOKIE and (b) bottom center where I  had ASKME then SEEME and didn't check the already-filled-in downs. Fly-specking time! No, POST did not work.
   Yes, secret to great cookies is definitely lots of  real butter and lots of good-quality chips (probably NOT the Nestles ones) and parchment paper on the cookie sheets. Learned at my mother's knee. She was the goto person for them at her church because everyone else cut corners.

Usually Tuesdays are a "fill=in-the-blank" process--not today's, tho. Started it on my lunch break, but there were enough holes that I couldn't finish it until I got home from work.

"It's amazing how many bad chocolate chip cookies thaere are out there, considering the best recipe for chocolate chip cookies is printed on every bag of Nestl√© toll-house chips."

This goes out to @andzrej: My good friend Vera was born in Prague (then Czechoslovakia), grew up in Canada and the US, but returned to live in Prague between the 1990's and 2020. Although she spoke Czech fluently (she did a lot of work as a transterpreter, mainly of legal documents), she really hung around with the community of American and Western European ex-pats that had moved there in the 90's. Among the Americans, there was a home-sickness for some American foods, chocolate chip cookies included, which couldn't be duplicated using the ingredients available in Eastern Europe at the time: chocolate chips were no problem--just buy a bar of chocolate and chop it up--but American-style brown sugar (without which it's impossible to make a good cookie) was; and Americans would smuggle bags of brown sugar in their luggage when they returned from visits home. I think things have changed a lot in the last 30 years, tho.

The dahlia originated in Mexico as well as C. America, so I will take this opportunity to remind everyone that Mexicans are NorteAmericanos.  They Certainly were when they owned California, Arizona, NMexico and Colorado.  They could ski then.

I have to day, I enjoyed the theme, but there were several answers that were shortened or abbreviated without being clued that way. 62A, mean, median and mode are examples of statistics, not "stats", (shortened without indication). 5D, REORGS, another shortened one. 22D, the use of "Insta" indicates a shortened answer but the answer is full. Others have pointed out 46D. 14A feels like very sloppy cueing and 43A seems ridiculous. Usually I don't comment complaining, I don't mind a few misses here and there. But there were so many in this puzzle; feels like sloppy editing.
Why is the answer SENT for THRILLED?
WE ARE!!

Tuesday evening thought: 
On most Mondays, and some Tuesdays as well, I will also work the New Yorker puzzles, as they tend to be more challenging on those days. Two weird coincidences today:
1) Both puzzles had clues [Make or break](NYer) and [Hit and run, but not error](NYT), solving to VERB[S].
2) My solve time was exactly 12'40" on both.

(Yesterday's NYer, which is billed as being "a challenging puzzle," was for me a breeze, as there was not one piece of literature, art, movie, or music trivia which I didn't know--two of the books mentioned were ones I had read.)
Awareness of bodily position is proprioception

We're going on 24 hours after the column and between people asking about SENT for [Thrilled], so I'm going to refer again to the amazing Sam Cooke. (I wanted this to be my wedding song, but "For Sentimental Reasons" was my aunt's favorite song and my sister talked me into the "I love you I love you I love you I love you I love you" song.) They're not dissimilar musically, but why mess with perfection. Darling, you send me I know you send me Darling, you send me Honest you do, honest you do Honest you do You thrill me I know you, you, you, you send me Darling, you, you, you, you thrill me Honest you do https://youtu.be/fz2-1G2lkeQ?si=1tztjm48wjF4FkKr

Oh wow.   I just got spanked by a Tuesday puzzle.    That was humbling.   I failed "MISS M", failed "MII", failed "TROTH, SENT, even ERAS".    Etc.
     The theme was a nice one tho.   Perhaps I'll have better luck on Wednesday.
@Steven M. Andrew Tappan Zee will probably be our next mayor.

@Steven M.
I think there‚Äôs always a repeated word in the mini and the full.

@Steven M. 

I understand the habit of calling things by their old name (cf. Sixth Avenue vs. Avenue of the Americas), but the CUOMO Bridge is a completely different bridge than the old Tappan Zee (albeit in the same place, more or less).

Interestingly, the new bridge couldn't be built exactly where the old one was, but it had to be built slightly upriver, not downriver, from the old one, in order that the Thruway Authority could control it, and not the Port Authority, which has rights to any Hudson River crossing up to a point that's just before where the old bridge was.

I'd like to see the city crossings with the old, more descriptive names--Triboro, Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, etc.--get their old names back.

@Steve L

Having those old names revived sounds like a bridge too far.

@Steve L 

I haven't lived in Brooklyn in many years, but I was shocked from reading what you wrote that it is no longer called the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel! I had to look it up. Hugh L. Carey Tunnel????? What were they thinking??? It will always be the Battery Tunnel.

Times Rita, 

In Queens, 
it is still called the 59th Street Bridge.

In Manhattan, 
it is still called the Queensboro Bridge.

I have not discovered 
where it is called the Ed Koch Bridge.

@Steve L 
A bridge of Theseus, perhaps?

@G 

The TZ and its successor, the Mario Cuomo, are 25 miles north of midtown Manhattan.
@Steven M. I'm not from New York. I've never heard of the Tappan Zee Bridge. I HAVE heard of one or more "Cuomo's" in relation to New York, so that clue was gettable for me.
@Megan Penn is in Philly. Two totally different schools.
@Megan "Penn" is the Ivy League (not Big Ten) University of Pennsylvania. But PSU is mostly referred to as "Penn State."
@Aaron   Penn State is in Happy Valley.  Never heard it called PSU,  but I suppose it must be on some school form or something.

@jennie 
Not to be confused with the state pen, which is something altogether different.

@Andrzej I was thinking SENT is like the modern usage (probably just AAVE) when people say ‚Äúthat sent me!‚Äù But it is usually in the context of something funny, so saying sent means thrilled seems a bit of a stretch to me too.

@Andrzej SENT = thrilled? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mrwfB4aAZZc CRONUTS are a cross between a croissant and a donut. Oatmeal raisin cookies are among my favorites, even though I hate eating oatmeal. My wife hates anything with raisins in it.
@Andrzej Here's some context for TOLLHOUSE COOKIE, courtesy of Friends. ;) https://youtu.be/7kb5xzKVZxA?si=2ZBkhQa-51qTGyD6

Thank you all.

So how about TROTH for engagement? Is there a link to betrothed? Anyway, I don't see a meaning of TROTH used in the puzzle in the dictionaries I'm looking it. Am I misunderstanding something?

@Andrzej 
Definition from MW. You're right that it's linked to betrothed and betrothal.   Some wedding vows has a line that goes something like "I pledge my troth to thee."

@Andrzej As a fellow non-American, only my extensive knowledge of Friends could help me with TOLL HOUSE. CRONUT also came from some show, not sure which one but I think I heard it in multiple - now I kinda want to try it!

I was also stuck on SENT, it was the last word I filled and only figured it out when filling in POSED. Still not sure when would I use it.

@Andrzej 

The Toll House cookie recipe is probably the most famous cookie recipe in the US.

@Elizabeth Connors 
Who knew that a biscuit/cookie could be in the history books! 
There is a brand 'Maryland' that is on sale in the UK, and I think this is the only time 'biscuits' are called 'cookies'. There are also giant ones. 
They are not really that popular, but there are a great many types of biscuit available. McVities Chocolate digestives are most popular, and Jaffa Cakes, Rich Tea, Hobnobs, custard creams, bourbons, ginger nuts, Garibaldi, Jammie Dodgers and many more.

@Jane Wheelaghan 
If your chocolate chip cookies are hard and dry, you're doing them wrong.

@Jane Wheelaghan 

I *loved* McVities Chocolate digestives when I first vistied England, in 1993 (it was Englad, specifically. I only ever visited another part of the UK once - on a short yet great trip to Scotland in 2014. We may go to the UK on holiday this year though, most likely England and Wales). The taste was unlike anything sold in Poland at the time. Thank you for reminding me of them :)

@Steve L

I must be half blind - I swear I only saw your reply just now. 

I'm trying to imagine how a croissant and donut could ever mesh into something. They are so unlike! Everything about them is different. The airy, slightly crunchy, buttery croissant could not be more unlike the lardy, rich, spongy donut.

I'm looking at cronuts online as I'm writing this, and while now I know what the pastry is about, I just can't see how it combines croissant-ness and donut-ness. It seems it's just a slightly modified donut? It looks like it tastes great though, which is most important :)

@Andrzej 
I don‚Äôt think anyone actually says troth outside of a Shakespeare play anymore.

@David 
Sent was the last word I filled in. Terrible clue for a Tuesday. This is not a widely used definition of the word despite the example people have stirred up.

@Jane Wheelaghan 
If you‚Äôre eating dry, hard chocolate chip cookies, the person making them doesn‚Äôt know what they‚Äôre doing! 
I‚Äôm not typically a fan of Subway sandwich shops, but at least in my area, they have the absolute best chocolate chip cookies. They‚Äôre almost underbaked so they are soft and gooey. Even better if slightly warmed. Yum! 
Sadly, I‚Äôm not indulging in anything like that right now as I‚Äôve just discovered I have a miserably large gallstone. I have had to drastically change my diet in a probably vane attempt to keep my gallbladder from being removed.

@Andrzej  and @Joya

All this time I was thinking "Quaker" because they call themselves "Friends"....

@ad absurdum 

Thank you, but you'd be surprised how often and in what ways my English fails me. It can be quite frustrating after so many years (almost 40 now!) of consciously trying to improve it.

@ everyone 

What a fantastic conversation!

@Andrzej 

"I'm trying to imagine how a croissant and donut could ever mesh into something. They are so unlike!" 

I think why it works is by virtue of the fact this confection was invented by a French master baker. Believe me, you do not want to try 99% of what passes for "croissants" in this country! (And you thought the bread was a problem! Hahaha.)

The cronut starts with gorgeous, laminated layers of croissant dough. And then is given the donut treatment! {Drool}

With apologies to @Dawn to have to read about that which she cannot have. Good luck and best wishes to feel better!

@Erick 

I have to agree with Steve L here.  The Mario is a new and different structure standing in a new location.  (As long as the bolts hold up.)

Unlike the avenue west of Fifth, which I and most others still call "Sixth Avenue". 

My family often used the Triborough when I was a child and I'd probably still call it that if it ever came up in conversation.

@Al  in Pittsburgh 

It took me a while to shift from saying "the Interborough" to "the Jackie Robinson" -- five syllables, up from four! But now everyone just calls it "the Jackie," which is nice and succinct. (If only the road itself were that straightforward, haha.)

@john ezra schwatastic is a new one haha

@dutchiris

@Sam

@Bruce 

As someone who has eaten Polish and American bread - that stuff you call bread is so different from what we get here you wouldn't believe! At a chain supermarket in Warsaw I can cheaply get better bread than anything I have ever bought at any American store. The stuff we were served at restaurants was quite underwhelming, too.

I am sure there is good bread to be had in the states - but it certainly seemed much harder to find than over here.

Also, I don't enjoy caraway seeds in my bread - their taste is so overpowering the bread could just as well be made of anything: rye, wheat, dust, woodchips - it would still taste only of those seeds.

@Andrzej

 I worked in industrial bakeries in the US for years. At one point I was a "vacation man," meaning I was trained to do anyone's job so that I could fill in for them.

There's plenty of people in the industry who know what good bread really is, and there's a market for it here as well, but it's still small. The majority of people here still prefer their soft, white, marshmallow-consistency bread, and if the companies that produced it started manufacturing something better on a the same scale that they currently make the soft, airy, tasteless stuff, most of it would go stale on the shelves.

The company I worked for allowed Its employees to take home two loaves of bread, free of charge. Over the course of my entire career I never did that.

@Andrzej I grew up outside San Francisco, and when my older siblings went into the City, they often get home with a half eaten fresh boule of Parisian brand sourdough.  The younger kids would fight over it.

Didn‚Äôt have bread that good until I lived in France for a while.

A few local bakeries are OK here, but still, Europe is simply another much higher level.

Parisian in the City went under about 20 years ago.

@Bruce 
Rye bread fresh from the bakery in Germany, with butter....I never could schieve the shiny, toothsome crust, but not for lack of trying!

@Mean Old Lady 

Try brushing egg wash on the surface just before it goes into the oven. There's lots of variations on egg wash online, and each has its own effect.

Or you could use a glaze. There's many variations of those, too 

Brush water on the surface if you want a crisp, crunchy crust.

@Bruce Years ago I was fascinated to learn the history of Wonder Bread; as I recall its invention was due in no small part to the perceived need for a consistent (homogenized) product, as well as to provide nutrition during the Great Depression (thus the added vitamins touted on the label). Incredible, right?? I learned this many years ago at the Queens Museum, which pre-renovation used to have a fantastic permanent exhibit about the two NYC World's Fairs. Wonder Bread was exhibited in 1939 as a scientific breakthrough-! https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wonder_Bread As a kid, we were *never* allowed Wonder Bread. Or sugary peanut butters like Jif or Skippy, or marshmallow fluff. Boy was that a treat at other kids' houses!

@Mean Old Lady 

You might also try steaming the bread as it bakes. Commercial ovens often have this option built in; you just push a button. Many home bakers approximate it by pouring water into an all-metal pan that has preheated in the bottom of the oven, then closing the door so that some of the steam remains.

I have a little homemade contraption for this. It's half a metal can, suspended at the top of the can via holes on either side to a coathanger-wire framework that's wired to the bottom rack of the oven. Beneath that rack is a cast iron skillet that stays there as the oven preheats. Fastened to the top lip of the can is a long brake cable from a bicycle. 

I open the oven door after preheating with a measuring cup of water in one hand, pour water into the can, put the bread in the oven on the top rack, close the door, and pull the cable. The can swings over like a porch swing on a framework, dumps the water into the hot skillet, and all of the resulting steam is contained in the shut oven.

Quite late in my life I realized I can literally have *anything* for breakfast. Leftover Indian food? Sure! A slice of pizza? Why not!

As kids we get taught all these rules only to realize most of them don't make sense at all :D

Also, at 44 I am still waiting for this mysterious adulting to kick in :D. As a child, teenager and young adult I expected something (what exactly? who knows?) will finally happen, and I will *become* an adult - a different sort of person than I was before. But nope. Stuff sort of happens all around me, and perhaps these days I am more of an actor than just a subject of this stuff, but everything stays generally the same. With more fun breakfasts :D

@G 

Pancakes for dinner is quite normal in Poland btw. Many people make them from scratch, and you can also buy them ready made - always made by hand and high quality, but still cheap. Nobody uses premade pancake mix here - I've never seen it on sale in Poland, so I was quite surprised when I encountered it in the US.

Our pancakes are more like crepes - not thick like American ones, but also not as thin as the French make them.

The simplest way to serve them is to just sprinkle them with sugar. You can also make them into a pocket filled with either sweetened twar√≥g (a sort of cottage cheese, but one I've never seen sold outside Poland and Germany, where it's known as Quark) or fruit, usually strawberries or blueberries. A version with an apricot-twar√≥g mix is also quite popular.

I find it remarkable how few people understand that the United States didn't just grow from the East coast west.  

It also grew from the south up.  The oldest European settlements in the south west are as old as those on the east coast.

It also grew from the Alaska southward, from Russians which established posts as far south as Fort Ross in California.

Very poor history taught in grade schools even  in the past.  I doubt they're doing much better these days.
